title: Week 2 - Analysis of Variance
text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from IPython.display import display, Markdown, Math, Latex


import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import statsmodels.api as sm

from scipy import stats

import patsy
from statsmodels.stats.anova import AnovaRM
from statsmodels.regression.mixed_linear_model import MixedLMResults

title: Week 2 - Analysis of Variance
text:
One-way ANOVA
O6 - Alkylquanine DNA alkyltransferase activity (AGT) and secondary leukemia

controls = [
    9.25, 7, 5.05, 6.9, 3.8, 9.5333, 7, 6.325, 6.05, 9, 4.0333, 8.0333, 7.1667, 5.775, 8.1, 8.7, 6.4, 5.775, 4.5, 3.2, 4.8333, 5, 11, 8.7, 5.875, 6.2, 9.6, 9.6333, 5.6, 10.45, 3.2, 8.4667, 8.3, 8.7, 8.3,
]

aml_de_novo = [11.15, 5.5, 5.2, 14.8, 4.4, 5.6]

aml_t = [5.15, 5.1, 1.7, 0.4, 5.5, 4.5, 6.7, 2.9667, 5.9, 3.8333, 5.55]


# Find the maximum length among all lists
max_length = max(len(controls), len(aml_de_novo), len(aml_t))

# Pad the shorter lists with NaN values to match the maximum length
controls += [np.nan] * (max_length - len(controls))
aml_de_novo += [np.nan] * (max_length - len(aml_de_novo))
aml_t += [np.nan] * (max_length - len(aml_t))


data = {"Controls": controls, "Primary": aml_de_novo, "Secondary": aml_t}
sl_df = pd.DataFrame(data)
sl_df

sns.catplot(data=sl_df_melt, x="Group", y="AGT", kind="box", aspect=2)









Assumptions of ANOVA

Each observation is independent of all other observations
Each sample must be randomly selected from the population (e.g.Â patients are randomized into different treatment groups)
Data is normally distributed
Variances of different populations are equal

The first two points are the most important.
If \(H_{0}\) is true:
\[\mu_{Controls} = \mu_{Primary} = \mu_{Secondary}\]

# scipy.stats
stats.f_oneway(
    sl_df_melt[sl_df_melt["Group"] == "Controls"]['AGT'],
    sl_df_melt[sl_df_melt["Group"] == "Primary"]['AGT'],
    sl_df_melt[sl_df_melt["Group"] == "Secondary"]['AGT']
)

F_onewayResult(statistic=6.447702046398812, pvalue=0.003267180257693189)


from https://nicoleeic.github.io/Brain_and_Code/2019/09/02/ANOVA_new.html
Steps to conducting an ANOVA:

Generate a model that fits our design
Fit our data to the model to get the parameter estimates
Derive stats from the summary function of the model


# 1. Generate a model that fits our design
# Linear regression

my_model = smf.ols(formula="AGT ~ Group", data=sl_df_melt)

my_model

<statsmodels.regression.linear_model.OLS at 0x7f8cc7f8a610>



# 2. Fit the data to the model

my_model_fit = my_model.fit()
my_model_fit

<statsmodels.regression.linear_model.RegressionResultsWrapper at 0x7f8cc7fb67d0>



# 3. Summarize the data

my_model_fit.summary()

title: Week 2 - Analysis of Variance
text:
Homework

Rheumatoid arthritis treatments
Duration of morning stiffness is measured for each of the three groups:

Placebo
Drug A
Drug B


ra_placebo = [5.2, 6.8, 5.6, 6.1]
ra_drug_a = [3.7, 2.4, 5.1, 1.8]
ra_drug_b = [4.8, 5.9, 4.0, 4.7]


ra_data = {"Placebo": ra_placebo, "Drug A":ra_drug_a, "Drug B":ra_drug_b}

ra_df = pd.DataFrame(ra_data)
display(ra_df)

ra_df_melt = pd.melt(ra_df, var_name='Treatment', value_name='Stiffness')









Placebo
Drug A
Drug B




0
5.2
3.7
4.8


1
6.8
2.4
5.9


2
5.6
5.1
4.0


3
6.1
1.8
4.7









sns.catplot(data=ra_df_melt, x='Treatment', y='Stiffness', kind='box')








Using scipy.stats:

stats.f_oneway(
    ra_df_melt[ra_df_melt["Treatment"] == "Placebo"]['Stiffness'],
    ra_df_melt[ra_df_melt["Treatment"] == "Drug A"]['Stiffness'],
    ra_df_melt[ra_df_melt["Treatment"] == "Drug B"]['Stiffness']
)

F_onewayResult(statistic=6.705474171164224, pvalue=0.016482391935724025)


Using statsmodels:

# 1. Generate a model that fits our design
# Linear regression
my_model = smf.ols(formula="Stiffness ~ Treatment", data=ra_df_melt)

# 2. Fit the data to the model
my_model_fit = my_model.fit()


# 3. Summarize the data

my_model_fit.summary()

Web notebook information
This is an online notebook generated as a quarto website. The jupyter notebooks are rendered (without execution) by a GitHub Action on a push to the main branch. Notebooks should be executed locally, so that the cell outputs are in the files, prior to commiting changes to git.

title: Week 1 - Introduction and Data Summarization
text:
import pandas as pd import numpy as np

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns 
from IPython.display import display, Markdown, Math, Latex



These problems have been taken from the following textbook, which is used in the course:
Glantzâs âPrimer of Biostatisticsâ1



# Import data
rna_levels_seroconversion = [79725, 12862, 18022, 76712, 256440, 14013, 46083, 6808, 85781, 1251, 6081, 50397, 11020, 13633, 1064, 496433, 25308, 6616, 11210, 13900]

rna_levels_sc_df = pd.DataFrame(rna_levels_seroconversion, columns=['RNA_Level'])


# Calculate the descriptive statistics 
rna_levels_sc_descriptive = pd.DataFrame(rna_levels_sc_df.describe().round(), dtype=int)
rna_levels_sc_descriptive









RNA_Level




count
20


mean
61668


std
117539


min
1064


25%
9967


50%
13956


75%
56976


max
496433









# Determining normality from descriptive stats

sc_mean = rna_levels_sc_descriptive.loc["mean", "RNA_Level"]
sc_median = rna_levels_sc_descriptive.loc["50%", "RNA_Level"]

mean_to_25th = sc_mean - rna_levels_sc_descriptive.loc["25%", "RNA_Level"]
mean_to_75th = sc_mean - rna_levels_sc_descriptive.loc["75%", "RNA_Level"]



From the descriptive statistics, the data does not appear to be normally distributed. First, there is some skew to the data, as the mean (61668) is far off from the median (13956).
Additionally, the difference between the mean and 25th percentile \(\neq\) difference between the mean and 75th percentile:
\[
\bar{x} - 25^{th}\ percentile = 51701
\]
\[
\bar{x} - 75^{th}\ percentile = 4692
\]
Therefore, we can say that the data appears to be not normally distributed, based on the descriptive statistics alone.



# Graphical confirmation
sns.histplot(data = rna_levels_seroconversion)












# Import Data
normalized_data = [4.90, 4.11, 4.26, 4.88, 5.41, 4.15, 4.66, 3.83, 4.93, 3.10, 3.78, 4.70, 4.04, 4.13, 3.03, 5.70, 4.40, 3.82, 4.05, 4.14]

normalized_data_df = pd.DataFrame(normalized_data, columns=['Pain_Score'])


# Calculate the descriptive statistics 
norm_data_descriptive = pd.DataFrame(normalized_data_df.describe().round(), dtype=int)
norm_data_descriptive









Pain_Score




count
20


mean
4


std
1


min
3


25%
4


50%
4


75%
5


max
6









# Determining normality from descriptive stats

norm_mean = norm_data_descriptive.loc["mean", "Pain_Score"]
norm_median = norm_data_descriptive.loc["50%", "Pain_Score"]

mean_to_25th = norm_mean - norm_data_descriptive.loc["25%", "Pain_Score"]
mean_to_75th = norm_data_descriptive.loc["75%", "Pain_Score"] - norm_mean



From the descriptive statistics, the data does appear to be normally distributed. First, the mean (4) \(=\) the median (4).
Additionally, the difference between the mean and 25th percentile \(\approx\) difference between the mean and 75th percentile:
\[
\bar{x} - 25^{th}\ percentile = 0
\]
\[
\bar{x} - 75^{th}\ percentile = 1
\]
Therefore, we can say that the data appears to be normally distributed, based on the descriptive statistics alone.



# Graphical confirmation
sns.histplot(data = normalized_data_df)














1. Glantz SA. Primer of Biostatistics. 7. ed. McGraw-Hill; 2012.

title: Week 1 - Introduction and Data Summarization

# Import data

mean_to_25th = sc_mean - rna_levels_sc_descriptive.loc["25%", "RNA_Level"]
mean_to_75th = sc_mean - rna_levels_sc_descriptive.loc["75%", "RNA_Level"]



From the descriptive statistics, the data does not appear to be normally distributed. First, there is some skew to the data, as the mean (61668) is far off from the median (13956).
Additionally, the difference between the mean and 25th percentile \(\neq\) difference between the mean and 75th percentile:
\[
\bar{x} - 25^{th}\ percentile = 51701
\]
\[
\bar{x} - 75^{th}\ percentile = 4692
\]
Therefore, we can say that the data appears to be not normally distributed, based on the descriptive statistics alone.



# Graphical confirmation
sns.histplot(data = rna_levels_seroconversion)












# Import Data
normalized_data = [4.90, 4.11, 4.26, 4.88, 5.41, 4.15, 4.66, 3.83, 4.93, 3.10, 3.78, 4.70, 4.04, 4.13, 3.03, 5.70, 4.40, 3.82, 4.05, 4.14]

normalized_data_df = pd.DataFrame(normalized_data, columns=['Pain_Score'])

mean_to_25th = norm_mean - norm_data_descriptive.loc["25%", "Pain_Score"]
mean_to_75th = norm_data_descriptive.loc["75%", "Pain_Score"] - norm_mean



From the descriptive statistics, the data does appear to be normally distributed. First, the mean (4) \(=\) the median (4).
Additionally, the difference between the mean and 25th percentile \(\approx\) difference between the mean and 75th percentile:
\[
\bar{x} - 25^{th}\ percentile = 0

\[

Therefore, we can say that the data appears to be normally distributed, based on the descriptive statistics alone.
